Its population of 400 in 35 households included Barés, Macús, Mariaranas, Mepuris, Passés, and Xomanas, who practiced subsistence agriculture, fishing, and extraction of local resources. Mariuá (Our Lady of the Conception of), later named Barcellos, was located on the southern bank of the Rio Negro between the Uatanari and Baruri rivers, opposite Buhibuhi, at latitude 00° 58' S, longitude 28° 23' W of Olinda, 91 leagues above the Rio Negro confluence and 169 from the mouth of the Jamundá. Originally a Manáos-Camandri village, it was granted to the Carmelite Mission and became the seat of the Captaincy of Rio Negro in 1758 under Governor Francisco Xavier de Mendonça Furtado. facts: Barcellos (formerly Mariuá) was elevated to a town in 1758 and made the seat of the Government of the Captaincy of Rio Negro, created in 1757.
Barcellos served as the capital of the province until 1790, when the capital was transferred to Lugar da Barra.
In 1798, Barcellos temporarily reclaimed its status as capital with the withdrawal of Governor Manoel da Gama Lobo da Almada.

context.value: The Pará revolution of 1835, led initially by Archpriest Baptista and later involving Malcher, resulted in widespread anarchy and social dissolution. Rebel forces known as cabanos controlled settlements temporarily but were unable to maintain lasting dominance. Gregorio Nazianzeno da Costa led a successful restoration on August 31, 1836, after which João Ignacio Rodrigues do Carmo became Military Commander of the District. Ambrósio Ayres, assembling a force in Bararoá, fought the cabanos along the Rio Negro, Maués River, and Icuipiranga, contributing to their surrender and becoming Military Commander. Pedro Ayres, claiming to be Ambrósio’s brother and a U.S. Navy officer, explored Guiana, the Rio Branco, and confronted the British at Fort St. Joaquim. A tailor from Stabrok, posing as a missionary, attempted to convert Indigenous people along the Pirarára River.

facts: In 1836, Gregorio Nazianzeno da Costa led a successful restoration against rebel control in the settlements along the Rio Negro.
João Ignacio Rodrigues do Carmo, Captain of the National Guard, assumed the Military Command of the District after the restoration.
Other settlements along the Rio Negro also freed themselves from rebel control following this example.

context.value: In February 1842, about seventy Black men in red uniforms, led by an English Colonel, invaded the Amazon frontier near the Pirarára River, built a sandbag redoubt, and placed boundary markers, sending a letter to the Government of Pará. In October 1842, Francisco Sergio d'Oliveira, Commander of Arms of the Province, inspected the last settlements of the Rio Branco below the waterfalls and ordered minor repairs to the Fortresses of St. Joaquim do Rio Branco and St. José de Marabitánas. The Diocesan Bishop, D. José Affonso de Moraes Torres, visited in 1848, and Manaus was elevated to city status in October 1848, later becoming a second-order province in 1850. The settlements along the Solimões and Rio Negro rivers declined after 1840, while only Manaus and Lusea experienced some growth. The rivers Uatumá, Urubu, Hiauapiri, Padauari, Araçá, Cauaburi, Uaupez, Japurá, Jutahi, and Juruá remained largely isolated.

facts: In the 19th century, the settlements of the Solimões and Rio Negro declined considerably, both in size and number, compared to their state in 1840.
Since the restoration, only the city of Manaus and the village of Lusea have seen some growth; the settlements of the Rio Negro have otherwise declined.
Education and social conditions in the Rio Negro settlements declined alongside the population and settlement decrease.

context.value: The Rio Branco was noted for its fertility, riches, and promise, leading Fernando da Costa de Athayde, general of the State, to recommend its settlement, pending royal approval. Missionaries, including the friar Mathias in Mariuá and others in their respective missions, made significant progress in converting local Indians by respecting their customs and avoiding coercion. The missionary plan, supported by royal orders and advocated by Vieira, aimed to keep Indians in their own settlements to prevent their ruin and deaths when relocated. Initially, mission villages excluded whites and people of mixed descent, but this separation was later abolished by the directory to promote civility, commerce, and integration.

facts: The sober friar Mathias made great progress in converting the natives in Mariuá (Thomar) in the Rio Negro region in the 19th century.
Missionaries in the Rio Negro region followed a method of gently introducing themselves into native settlements, studying their customs, and gradually introducing useful and honest practices.
The directory abolished the separation between Indians and residents of white or mixed descent in the villages, promoting civility, commerce, and good society.

context.value: On February 7, 1842, a colonel, three officers, and forty English soldiers with three cannons built a fort and raised the British flag at Pirarà on the shores of Lake Amacû. Missionary José dos Santos Innocentes withdrew to the fort of San-Joaquin following this event. Lake Amacù and its surroundings were subsequently declared neutral territory by agreement between the two nations. The upper Rio Branco region, affected by the insurrection of Praia de Sangues, saw its population drop to about a thousand, with many Indians relocating to Dutch Surinam. The Rio Negro, called Gruriquacurû by the Indians, is over 300 leagues long, navigable for 160 leagues above its confluence, and obstructed by cataracts such as Maracabi, Cojubi, Turnas, Crocobi, Caldeirão, Paredão, and Caranguejo; its banks are home to thirty or forty still wild nations. Captain-Major Pedro Texeira first traveled the Rio Negro in 1637, discovering its mouth while ascending the Amazon to Peru, after which missionaries founded settlements along its banks.

facts: Since the time of Pedro Texeira's exploration in 1637, several missionaries have founded settlements on the Rio Negro to convert the indigenous populations.
In the 19th century, the banks of the Rio Negro were home to thirty or forty still wild nations.
Beautiful rice fields were beginning to be established near the lagoons on the banks of the Rio Negro in the 19th century.

agent_thoughts: Previous cycles established Bararoá as a large multiethnic mission and trading post on the Rio Negro, destroyed in 1757 and reconstituted as Thomar in 1758. It was a significant node in the Directory system but declined after its abolition. So far, I have not found precise details on the post-mission, post-Directory trajectory—whether the settlement persisted, was reabsorbed, depopulated, or renamed again. I am now targeting information about Thomar in the 19th century, seeking evidence of any surviving population, administration, or subsequent fate of the location.
